newsitem.title: USA: Dole ends long campaign hoping for Truman-like upset.
newsitem.headline: Dole ends long campaign hoping for Truman-like upset.

text.p: - The long, exhausting presidential campaign of Republican Bob Dole came to a close in the pre-dawn dampness early on Tuesday in the hometown of come-from-behind Democratic legend Harry Truman.

The final stop of Dole's 96-hour "march to victory" came before a courthouse statue of Truman, the Democrat who pulled off one of America's greatest political upsets when he defied opinion polls to defeat Republican Tom Dewey in 1948.
Dole, too, was hoping for an upset. The latest Reuters/Zogby poll showed him lagging behind President Bill Clinton by 7.3 points and was further behind in several other opinion surveys.
Several thousand people turned out in Independence to cheer Dole on a foggy, damp morning as he delivered his speech at 3 a.m. local time (0900 GMT).
"What was true for Harry Truman in 1948 will be true for Bob Dole and Jack Kemp in 1996," said the 73-year-old campaigner. "The people are once again going to win this election today."
From Independence, Dole heads later to his hometown of Russell, Kansas, where he planned to vote at mid-day.

Dole's stop at the Truman statue climaxed a 96-hour, whirlwind rush through 19 states that began Friday. He kept up a breakneck pace around the clock, stopping for only a few hours of sleep in his last-ditch bid to defeat Clinton.
On the last day of the campaign, Dole nearly lost his voice. But in Independence, he seemed to find renewed energy and spoke strongly.
"I recall the last time I fought round the clock for my country was in Italy in 1945," said Dole, refering to his service in the Second World War.
"Since noon last Friday, I have been fighting around the clock for America's future," he added.

"With every rally and every handshake, I have felt our momentum increase, particularly in the last 10 days. The tide of this election, I believe, was turned in diners and bowling alleys, in the heart of a people where the old values endure," he said.

Getting in another jab at Clinton over the ethics issue he has been underscoring in the last few weeks of the campaign, Dole said the nation "deserves and demands a president worthy of its honesty, worthy of its decency, worthy of its trust.
"I have done what I can do -- all I can do -- to make the stakes of this election, and the contrast of our visions, clear to every voter," he said."
Earlier Tuesday morning in a Des Moines, Iowa, bowling alley, Dole predicted that "a lot of people are going to be surprised tomorrow."
He spoke as his aides touted as a hopeful omen the first election returns from the hamlet of Dixville Notch, New Hampshire, where the nation's first voters went for Dole 18 to 8.
At the bowling alley, Dole's life was summed up by Sen. John McCain, an Arizona Republican and onetime Navy pilot who spent years as a prisoner of war in Vietnam.
"You know Bob Dole," said McCain quietly to hundreds of Dole supporters who came to bid good luck to Dole on Election Day.

"This is the last crusade of a great warrior, a member of a generation of Americans who went out and made the world safe for democracy so that we could have lives that were better for ourselves and our children," McCain said.
Dole, his right arm permanently crippled when a Nazi shell tore into it in Italy 51 years ago, stood silently by, seemingly choked up by McCain's remarks.
